questions.question: The period from 1920 to 1947 in the Indian national movement is known as the ________.
questions.answer: Gandhian Era

questions.question: In which year did Mahatma Gandhi return to India from South Africa?
Who suggested that Gandhiji should make a tour of the entire nation after returning to India?
questions.answer: Gopal Krishna Gokhale

questions.question: The new technique of agitation based on Truth and Non-violence used by Gandhiji is called ________.
questions.answer: Satyagraha

questions.question: Where was the first Satyagraha in India launched by Gandhiji?
questions.answer: Champaran

questions.question: In Champaran, the cultivators were forced to cultivate ________.
questions.answer: Indigo

questions.question: Why did Gandhiji start a Satyagraha in the Kheda district of Gujarat in 1918?

options.text: For increase in wages of mill workers
To demand tax remission due to crop failure

questions.answer: To demand tax remission due to crop failure

questions.question: The Ahmedabad Mill Strike was organized to demand ________.
questions.answer: Increase in wages

questions.question: The Rowlatt Act was passed in the year ________.
Which act gave the government the power to arrest and imprison anyone without a warrant?
questions.answer: Rowlatt Act

questions.question: What did the Rowlatt Act exclude for the arrested person?
questions.answer: Right to appeal in court

questions.question: Gandhiji appealed to observe ________ as a day of national protest against the Rowlatt Act.
questions.answer: 6 April 1919

questions.question: The Jallianwala Baug massacre took place on the occasion of ________ festival.
questions.answer: Baisakhi

questions.question: Who was the officer responsible for the Jallianwala Baug firing?
questions.answer: General Dyer

questions.question: The massacre at Jallianwala Baug occurred in the city of ________.
questions.answer: Amritsar

questions.question: As a protest against the Jallianwala Baug massacre, Rabindranath Tagore renounced his title of ________.
questions.answer: Sir

questions.question: The Khilafat Movement was started to support the Sultan of ________.
questions.answer: Turkey

questions.question: The resolution of Non-co-operation movement was passed in the ________ session of Congress in 1920.
questions.answer: Nagpur

questions.question: Who moved the resolution of Non-co-operation movement in the Nagpur session?
questions.answer: Chittaranjan Das

questions.question: What was the reason for Gandhiji to suspend the Non-co-operation Movement in 1922?
questions.answer: Chauri Chaura incident

questions.question: In the Chauri Chaura incident, a police station was set on fire in ________ province.
questions.answer: Uttar Pradesh

questions.question: The Swaraj Party was established by ________.

options.text: Lala Lajpat Rai and Bipinchandra Pal

questions.answer: Motilal Nehru and Chittaranjan Das

questions.question: What was the objective of the Swaraj Party?

options.text: To contest elections and enter legislative councils

questions.answer: To contest elections and enter legislative councils

questions.question: The Simon Commission was appointed by the British Government in ________.
Why did Indians boycott the Simon Commission?

options.text: It was led by General Dyer
There was not a single Indian member in it

questions.answer: There was not a single Indian member in it

questions.question: What slogan was used by Indians during the Simon Commission protest?
questions.answer: Simon Go Back

questions.question: Which leader died as a result of a lathi charge during the Simon Commission protest?
questions.answer: Lala Lajpat Rai

questions.question: Who was the chairman of the committee that drafted the 'Nehru Report'?
questions.answer: Motilal Nehru

questions.question: The Nehru Report demanded ________ for India.
questions.answer: Dominion Status

questions.question: In which session did the Congress pass the resolution for 'Purna Swaraj' (Complete Independence)?
questions.answer: Lahore (1929)

questions.question: Who presided over the Lahore session of the Indian National Congress in 1929?
questions.answer: Jawaharlal Nehru

questions.question: Which river bank was the venue for the Lahore session in 1929?
questions.answer: Ravi

questions.question: What date was decided to be celebrated as Independence Day in the Lahore session?
questions.answer: 26 January

questions.question: Which of these leaders represented the youth in Congress and demanded 'Purna Swaraj'?
questions.answer: Subhas Chandra Bose

questions.question: The first 'Independence Day' was celebrated on 26 January ________.
The Satyagraha in Champaran was launched in the year ________.
Which movement was launched in India as a result of the ill-treatment of the Khalif in Turkey?
questions.answer: Khilafat Movement

questions.question: In 1921, during the Non-co-operation movement, there was a strike of workers in the ________ tea gardens.
questions.answer: Assam

questions.question: Which prominent leaders were members of the Swaraj Party?
questions.answer: Motilal Nehru and C.R. Das

questions.question: The lathi charge on Lala Lajpat Rai occurred in the city of ________.
questions.answer: Lahore

questions.question: Who gave the order of lathi charge on the Simon Commission protesters in Lahore?
questions.answer: Officer Saunders

questions.question: Who challenged Indians by saying they were incapable of drafting a constitution?
questions.answer: Lord Birkenhead

questions.question: Which river was designated as the boundary in the Lahore session for hoisting the Tricolour?
questions.answer: Ravi

questions.question: The 'Purna Swaraj' resolution was passed under the leadership of ________.
questions.answer: Jawaharlal Nehru

questions.question: What was the main philosophy of Satyagraha?

options.text: Arousing the conscience of the oppressor through truth and non-violence

questions.answer: Arousing the conscience of the oppressor through truth and non-violence

questions.question: In which country did Gandhiji first test his technique of Satyagraha?
questions.answer: South Africa

questions.question: The Jallianwala Baug massacre happened because of the protest against the arrest of ________.

options.text: Dr. Satyapal and Dr. Saifuddin Kitchlew

questions.answer: Dr. Satyapal and Dr. Saifuddin Kitchlew

questions.question: Which of the following was NOT a part of the Non-co-operation movement program?

options.text: Boycott of government schools and colleges
Boycott of courts and legislative councils

questions.answer: Armed rebellion against the police

questions.question: Who took up the title of 'Kaisar-i-Hind'?
questions.answer: Gandhiji

questions.question: What did the Indians pledge on 26 January 1930?

options.text: To support the British in World War II
To carry on the freedom movement for attainment of Purna Swaraj
To pay taxes to the British government

questions.answer: To carry on the freedom movement for attainment of Purna Swaraj

questions.question: What principles defined Mahatma Gandhi's approach to the freedom movement?
questions.answer: Truth, Non-violence, and Satyagraha were the core principles of Gandhi's approach.

questions.question: In what year did Lokmanya Tilak die, passing leadership to Gandhi?
questions.answer: Lokmanya Tilak died in 1920, after which Gandhi took over the leadership of the national movement.

questions.question: What was the profession that took Gandhi to South Africa in 1893?
questions.answer: Gandhi went to South Africa for legal work as a lawyer.

questions.question: What was the identity system imposed on Black people in South Africa in 1906?
questions.answer: In 1906, the government made it compulsory for Black people to carry an identity card at all times, restricting their freedom.

questions.question: Who advised Gandhi to tour India upon his return?
questions.answer: Gopal Krishna Gokhale advised Gandhi to tour the entire nation after his return from South Africa.

questions.question: Where did Gandhi establish his ashram after returning to India?
questions.answer: Gandhi established his ashram at Sabarmati in Ahmedabad, Gujarat.

questions.question: What is the literal meaning of 'Satyagraha'?
questions.answer: Satyagraha literally means 'insistence on truth' or 'truth force'.

questions.question: How should a person following Satyagraha behave according to Gandhi?
questions.answer: A person following Satyagraha should never use violence or untruthful means.

questions.question: Which American civil rights leader was influenced by Gandhi's methods?
questions.answer: Martin Luther King Jr., who fought for African American rights, was influenced by Gandhi's Satyagraha.

questions.question: What crop were Champaran farmers forced to grow?
questions.answer: Farmers in Champaran, Bihar, were forced to cultivate indigo against their will.

questions.question: Why did the Champaran farmers suffer economically?
questions.answer: They received only a fixed, low payment from the planters for their indigo crops, regardless of market value or their costs.

questions.question: What natural disaster led to the Kheda Satyagraha?
questions.answer: Constant famines and crop failures in the Kheda district of Gujarat led to the Kheda Satyagraha.

questions.question: What action did Gandhi advise the Kheda farmers to take?
questions.answer: He advised them to refuse to pay the unjust land tax demanded by the government despite crop failure.

questions.question: What was the outcome of the Ahmedabad mill workers' strike?
questions.answer: After a hunger strike advised by Gandhi, the mill owners relented and increased the workers' salaries.

questions.question: Why were Indians hopeful of political reform after World War I?
questions.answer: Because Indians had supported Britain in the war, they expected a system of governance that considered their well-being.

questions.question: Who chaired the committee that led to the Rowlatt Act?
questions.answer: The committee was appointed under Sir Sydney Rowlatt.

questions.question: When was the Rowlatt Act passed?
questions.answer: The Rowlatt Act was passed on March 17, 1919.

questions.question: What power did the Rowlatt Act grant the government?
questions.answer: It granted the power to arrest anyone without a warrant and imprison them without a trial, with no right of appeal.

questions.question: What was the popular name for the Rowlatt Act among Indians?
questions.answer: Indians called it the 'Black Act' due to its oppressive nature.

questions.question: Which religious festival was being celebrated on the day of the Jallianwala Bagh massacre?
questions.answer: It was Baisakhi, a major Sikh and harvest festival.

questions.question: How many rounds of ammunition were fired at Jallianwala Bagh?
questions.answer: Approximately 1,660 rounds were fired by General Dyer's troops.

questions.question: What was imposed on Punjab after the Jallianwala Bagh massacre?
questions.answer: Martial law (military rule) was imposed across the entire province of Punjab.

questions.question: Who was the Governor of Punjab held responsible for the Jallianwala Bagh massacre?
questions.answer: General Michael O'Dwyer, the Governor of Punjab, was held responsible.

questions.question: What commission was appointed to investigate the Jallianwala Bagh massacre?
questions.answer: The British government appointed the Hunter Commission to investigate.

questions.question: Who was considered the Khalifa by Muslims worldwide?
questions.answer: The ruler (Sultan) of the Ottoman Empire in Turkey was considered the Khalifa, or Caliph, the religious leader.

questions.question: Why were Indian Muslims angry with the British after World War I?
questions.answer: The British had broken their promise to protect the Turkish Khalifa's empire after the war, leading to its dismemberment.

questions.question: What was Gandhi's strategic reason for supporting the Khilafat Movement?
questions.answer: He saw it as an opportunity to forge a strong Hindu-Muslim alliance against British rule.

questions.question: What did the Khilafat Committee accept from Gandhi?
questions.answer: The Khilafat Committee accepted Gandhi's proposal of adopting a policy of non-cooperation against the government.

questions.question: What was the core theory behind Non-Cooperation?
questions.answer: The theory was that British rule in India depended entirely on Indian cooperation; withdrawing it would cause the administration to collapse.

questions.question: Which Congress session formally launched the Non-Cooperation Movement?
questions.answer: The Nagpur session of the Indian National Congress in 1920 formally launched the movement.

questions.question: Who was entrusted with leading the Non-Cooperation Movement?
questions.answer: Mahatma Gandhi was given complete charge of leading the Non-Cooperation Movement.

questions.question: What did the Non-Cooperation program ask people to boycott?
questions.answer: It asked people to boycott government offices, courts, foreign goods, government schools, and colleges.

questions.question: What replaced government schools and colleges during the boycott?
questions.answer: A parallel system of national schools, colleges, and universities was established.

questions.question: How did Indians protest the visit of the Prince of Wales in 1921?
questions.answer: They observed a nationwide hartal (strike), keeping shops closed and streets empty to give him a 'lonely' welcome.

questions.question: Which sections of society participated in the Non-Cooperation Movement beyond cities?
questions.answer: It spread to planters in Assam and railway workers in Bengal, showing its reach to workers and peasants.

questions.question: What violent incident occurred at Chauri Chaura?
questions.answer: A police station was set on fire by an angry mob, leading to the deaths of 22 policemen and one officer.

questions.question: On what exact date did Gandhi suspend the Non-Cooperation Movement?
questions.answer: Gandhi suspended the movement on February 12, 1922.

questions.question: Where did the Mulshi Satyagraha take place?
questions.answer: It took place in Mulshi Taluka, in the Pune district of Maharashtra.

questions.question: Who led the Mulshi Satyagraha and what was his punishment?
questions.answer: Senapati Pandurang Mahadev Bapat led it and was sentenced to six years of imprisonment.

questions.question: For what publication was Gandhi arrested in March 1922?
questions.answer: He was arrested for writing articles in his journal 'Young India' that were deemed anti-national by the British.

questions.question: Where was Gandhi's trial held and what was his sentence?
questions.answer: A special court was set up in Ahmedabad, and Gandhi was sentenced to six years in prison.

questions.question: Why was Gandhi released from prison early?
questions.answer: He was released on grounds of ill health before completing his six-year sentence.

questions.question: Name two key leaders who founded the Swaraj Party.
questions.answer: Chittaranjan Das and Motilal Nehru were the key founders of the Swaraj Party.

questions.question: What was the main strategy of the Swaraj Party?
questions.answer: Their strategy was to contest elections, enter legislative councils, and obstruct British governance from within.

questions.question: Which prominent leaders were elected from the Swaraj Party in 1923?
questions.answer: Motilal Nehru, Madan Mohan Malaviya, Lala Lajpat Rai, and N.C. Kelkar were elected.

questions.question: What did the Swaraj Party demand in the Legislative Assembly?
questions.answer: They demanded the release of political prisoners and the calling of a Round Table Conference.

questions.question: Why was the Montagu-Chelmsford Act of 1919 considered unsatisfactory?
questions.answer: It provided very limited self-governance and did not meet Indian aspirations for responsible government.

questions.question: Why was the Simon Commission of 1927 formed?
questions.answer: It was formed to review and recommend further constitutional reforms for India.

questions.question: What was the major flaw in the composition of the Simon Commission?
questions.answer: It had no Indian members; it was composed entirely of British parliamentarians.

questions.question: What was the universal protest slogan against the Simon Commission?
questions.answer: The slogan was 'Simon Go Back!'

questions.question: Who was the British police officer who attacked Lala Lajpat Rai?
questions.answer: Police officer Saunders led the lathi charge that injured Lala Lajpat Rai.

questions.question: What did Lala Lajpat Rai predict about the blows he received?
questions.answer: He said, 'Every blow on my body will prove a nail in the coffin of the British Empire.'

questions.question: Who issued the challenge that Indian leaders couldn't draft a constitution?
questions.answer: Lord Birkenhead, the Secretary of State for India, issued this challenge.

questions.question: What was the main purpose of forming the committee for the Nehru Report?
questions.answer: It was formed to draft a constitution for India in response to Birkenhead's challenge, proving Indian capability.

questions.question: Who chaired the committee that prepared the Nehru Report?
questions.answer: Pandit Motilal Nehru was the chairman of the All-Party Committee that drafted the Nehru Report.

questions.question: What key voting right did the Nehru Report propose?
questions.answer: It proposed the implementation of the Adult Franchise system, giving all adults the right to vote.

questions.question: What was the Congress's ultimatum regarding the Nehru Report?
questions.answer: The Congress warned that if the government did not accept the report by the end of 1929, they would launch a Civil Disobedience Movement.

questions.question: What was the previous goal of the Congress before the Lahore session of 1929?
questions.answer: The previous goal was to achieve 'Dominion Status' for India within the British Empire.

questions.question: What new goal was adopted at the Lahore session in December 1929?
questions.answer: The Congress adopted 'Poorna Swaraj' or complete independence as its goal.

questions.question: Who presided over the historic Lahore session of 1929?
questions.answer: Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru presided over the Lahore session.

questions.question: What significant action did Nehru take on December 31, 1929?
questions.answer: He unfurled the tricolor flag of India at the Lahore session.

questions.question: What was declared about January 26th in the Lahore session resolution?
questions.answer: It was declared that henceforth, January 26th would be celebrated as India's Independence Day.

questions.question: What did people pledge to do on the first Independence Day, January 26, 1930?
questions.answer: People across the country took a pledge to achieve India's independence through non-violent means.

questions.question: Name two young leaders who strongly advocated for Poorna Swaraj.
questions.answer: Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru and Subhash Chandra Bose were strong advocates for complete independence.

questions.question: What was the name of the journal Gandhi edited?
questions.answer: Gandhi edited the journal 'Young India'.

questions.question: What was the purpose of Gandhi's constructive programs?
questions.answer: They aimed to build a self-reliant nation from the ground up by addressing social issues and promoting Indian products and unity.

questions.question: List three social issues targeted by Gandhi's constructive programs.
questions.answer: Three issues were the removal of untouchability, prohibition of alcohol, and the promotion of Hindu-Muslim unity.

questions.question: How did the Non-Cooperation Movement impact the rural national movement?
questions.answer: Gandhi's constructive programs, launched alongside the movement, made the national struggle more comprehensive and deeply rooted in rural India.

questions.question: What was the immediate British reaction to the growing Non-Cooperation Movement?
questions.answer: The British government undertook severe repressive measures to try and bring the movement under control.

questions.question: What did Gandhi prove with the success of his early Satyagrahas like Champaran and Kheda?
questions.answer: He proved that organized, non-violent mass resistance could successfully challenge injustice and achieve concrete results.
